title: World’s scariest haunted house is so terrifying you must produce doctor's note

It claims to be the world's scariest house, but according to its critics it is in fact a "torture chamber in disguise".

An online petition has been launched to close down events held at McKamey Manor which is advertised as "an extreme haunt'.

The events held at the US haunts located in Summertown, Tennessee and Huntsville, Alabama are so terrifying that participants must produce a doctor's note.

They also need to sign a 40-page waiver, pass a background check and drugs test and be screened via facetime or using their phone first.

(Image: Caters News Agency)

Once they are accepted they can take part in the different events which can last up to 10 hours.

Anyone who completes them are offered $20,000 (£15,600).

Organiser Russ McKamey boasts that the experiences are so petrifying that not one person has finished his current haunt 'Desolation'.

But according to the petition, set up by Frankie Towery, McKamey Manor is a "kidnapping and torture" venue.

(Image: Caters News Agency)

He wrote: "It’s a torture chamber under disguise. They do screenings to find the weakest, most easily manipulated people to do the 'haunt.'

"It's literally just a kidnapping and torture house. Some people have had to seek professional psychiatric help and medical care for extensive injuries.

"It is seriously just torture porn."

He is also claimed participants were waterboarded and forced to eat things.

(Image: Caters News Agency)

The petition has attracted more than 57,000 signatures with some people explaining on the page why they back Frankie.

Sandra Seymour said: "This 'attraction' targets susceptible and vulnerable people with the promise of a large sum of money in order to torture them."

Yvone Christy said: "I am signing this because I watched a youtube video on this and it is definitely not a haunt it is pure torture."

Participants who pass the checks must watch a two-hour video that shows people taking part in previous experiences and failed.

(Image: Caters News Agency)

Throughout the video the phrase "You really don't want to do this" is repeatedly spoken.

Participants don't have to pay money but they are asked to bring food for Russ' dogs.

However according to Frankie this is a loophole as it means participants are "doing it for fun".

Russ told WGNTV : "I’m a very straight-laced conservative guy, but here I run this crazy haunted house that people think is this torture factory, fetish factory.

(Image: Caters News Agency)

"All of these things that it’s not, but people believe that based upon the films that I have made."

He claims he has been reported to the police a number of times which is one of the reasons why he films the experiences.

"When you have that kind of power over people... they’ll go to the authorities," he said.

"I have to come back and show the footage and say, ‘it didn’t go that way at all.’ It’s saved me a thousand times.”

(Image: Caters News Agency)

Russ says he spent more than $1million on the experience which are inspired by classic horror films including Vertigo and Psycho.

A notice on its website says: "Be warned, McKamey Manor is not your standard (boo) haunted house. This is an audience participation event in which you will live your own horror movie.

"This is a rough, intense and truly frightening experience. You must be in great health to participate .

"Anyone that has been drinking alcohol, or taking drugs will not be allowed into the haunt and will be asked to leave the property."

(Image: Caters News Agency)

The website also says the experience is not recommended to anyone who is "a big whimp".

Mirror Online has contacted Russ for a comment.
description: Events held at McKamey Manor are so terrifying that participants must sign a 40-page waiver - but critics say it's a 'torture chamber in disguise'
